H0.text: Refracted is what most of the light becomes when it hits a mirror.

H1.text: Reflected light is most of the light when light hits a mirror.

H2.text: Absorbed is what most of the light becomes when it hits a mirror.

H3.text: Transmitted is the majority of the light when light hits a mirror.

A4.text: In the most general case, a certain fraction of the light is reflected from the interface, and the remainder is refracted.

A5.text: Note that these are theoretical ideals, requiring perfect alignment of perfectly smooth, perfectly flat perfect reflectors that absorb none of the light.

A6.text: Polished metallic objects can specularly reflect light very efficiently.

A7.text: The reflecting material of mirrors is usually aluminum or silver.

A8.text: An opaque object does not allow light to transmit through and instead reflecting or absorbing the light it receives.
